Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

More than 3,000 students and alumni signed petitions seeking a "more appropriate" commencement speaker. Cheney spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Wilhelm to deliver a commencement speech because of Wilhelm's pro-choice views. Off-campus protesters then threatened to disrupt the graduation ceremony. The college disinvited Wilhelm.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The president stated: "I decided it [having Wilhelm come speak] had the potential to mar our graduation ceremonies that are truly celebratory events for our students and families."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
The Columbia Political Union, a nonpartisan student group, canceled an event featuring Gilchrist because disruptive protests had erupted during Gilchrist's previous on-campus appearance.
A year after the university disinvited Ahmadinejad from campus, faculty and students opposed his reinvitation. Despite some heckling, Ahmadinejad spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president said to Ahmadinejad during his introduction:  "Mr. President, you exhibit all the signs of a petty and cruel dictator, [and denial of the Holocaust might fool] the illiterate and ignorant, [but] when you come to a place like this, it makes you quite simply ridiculous."

Controversy Explanation: The university president disinvited Lamott from delivering a commencement speech because of Lamott's support for assisted suicide.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression.  University officials stated: "We have decided that the key points she [Lamott] makes are in opposition to Catholic teaching. . . .We have decided that the key points she makes are in opposition to Catholic teaching. That makes her an inappropriate choice.”

A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
Horowitz ended his speech early because members of the audience (outsiders and students) screamed accusations of homophobia, sexism, and racism at him.
Public Response: Neutral. The university president said: "I'm confident that our Emory community would have expressed its support or disdain in a method more consistent with academic discourse. . . . It is a sad reminder that the sort of ideals that we hold as community at Emory are not universally appreciated and practiced."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. Student Affairs did not approve the performance, so the student organizers held it off campus.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place, although the university Culture and Performance Living and Learning Community's faculty advisor refused to subsidize tickets for the play as it customarily does for other theater productions.

The professor who invited Trivers disinvited him after Trivers criticized Israel and called a Harvard professor a Nazi. A different professor then invited Trivers a year later, and Trivers spoke successfully.
Public Response: None ("Harvard officials could not be reached for comment about why the talk was called off.")

Evangelical students and alumni objected to Romney's invitation to speak at a commencement because they did not want a Mormon speaking at the graduation ceremony for an Evangelical Christian school. Romney spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. A dean said that "the problem with Mitt Romney’s religion speech today is that the former Massachusetts Governor sought to place Mormonism under the umbrella of Christendom, where for many evangelical voters, it does not belong."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Scientific Views, Sexuality, Civil Liberties
Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Coakley to deliver a commencement speech because of Coakley's views on abortion and her support for stem-cell research and gay marriage. Coakley spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
University administrators canceled Watson's lecture after some members of the community objected to Watson's remarks regarding race and intelligence.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. Director of communications' statement included: “There were some members of the university community who had expressed reservations about Dr. Watson coming here to speak after the controversy over his remarks in the U.K.”

Controversy Explanation: Administrators denied student requests to host the play, The Vagina Monologues, at the university because they deemed the performance "inappropriate." The student organizers hosted the play off-campus.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  The university's VP for Student Affairs told organizers: "We fully support the value of raising awareness and education on systematic violence against women. . . . As part of our obligation to the entire university community, we also reserve the right not to support student life activities that we deem inappropriate."

Students petitioned the college to disinvite Alito because of Alito's rulings on issues related to women's rights. Alito spoke successfully.
Public Response: None (no official response -- admin assistant to president supported speech in general but said president wasn't commenting)

An official from the New York Chinese government consulate asked the college to cancel a talk by the Dalai Lama. The college did not rescind the Dalai Lama's invitation and he spoke successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Foreign Affairs
Controversy Explanation: 29 faculty members sent the president an open letter maintaining that the war in Iraq runs afoul of Catholic teachings and that Bush's policies "protect the privileges of rich and powerful Americans." The college's former president authored an op-ed titled, "Mr. President, this place is not your place," opposing Bush's invitation. Bush spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The chancellor of the college said: “I think any political Figure is going to have people that are supportive and those that are not supportive. . . . I think irrespective of the president’s political views or policies, he is the president of the United States. He’s the most powerful political Figure in the world. And it is a great honor for St. Vincent to welcome him.”

Controversy Explanation: Students protested Pipes' invitation because they viewed him as being anti-Islam. Pipes spoke successfully.
The UC Board of Regents rescinded an invitation to Summers because of Summers' comments about women in the sciences.

Protesters heckled Darwish throughout her talk. During the talk, police ejected multiple protesters, who continued to make noise in the hallway, and a scuffle broke out. The event went on longer than scheduled, but Darwish finished her remarks.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous), Appeased Protesters. The university chancellor said: “You [Students at the Pride Not Prejudice table] are doing the right thing. . . . My pride lies with Peace Not Prejudice because they are conducting themselves in a dignified manner when they are being subjected to insult.”

Controversy Explanation: Students attempted to disrupt Pipes' speech because of his pro-Israel views. Several were escorted out by university officials. Pipes spoke successfully despite the disruptions.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A student affairs spokesperson stated: "As a public university, UC Irvine has the responsibility to assure that all persons may exercise their constitutionally protected rights to free expression, speech and assembly. This includes acts of nonviolent protest and dissent. The first amendment protects speech and expression that we may find deeply offensive or unpopular. . . . I want to assure you that UC Irvine will be vigilant in protecting the constitutional free speech rights and the safety of all members of the campus community and visitors."

A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Coleman to deliver a commencement speech because of Coleman's views on abortion, support for stem-cell research, and refusal to cancel a course at the University of Michigan — where she was then-president — titled "How to Be Gay." Coleman spoke successfully.
